This award from the Division of Materials Research to New Mexico State University provides supports for students to attend the 2013-2014 Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE) Schools on Neutron Scattering. The LANSCE neuton schools are intended to cover a particular science topic, for which neutron scattering has made or is expected to make a major impact. The 2013 and 2014 LANSCE Schools on Neutron Scattering will focus on Geosciences and Materials in Extreme Environments and Mesoscale Sciences and Interfaces, respectively. Each of the annual schools will run for 9-10 days and they consist of formal lectures and hands-on experiments, using the neutron scattering facilities at the LANSCE.
The main objectives of both school are: a) to provide in-depth neutron-scattering training in a particular topic (in particular, for graduate students in their early stage of thesis research), b) to attract new users to the neutron-scattering community, c) to increase diversity among expert neutron scatterers, and d) to broaden the field where neutron scattering can develop further.
The number of student participants is limited to ~30 students, selected from a large applicant pool using a variety of criteria. A particular emphasis is put on selecting a diverse student body in order to foster a cross-institutional, cross-disciplinary and multicultural learning environment. This grant will support travel and meals for accepted student participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Neutron scattering is an extremely powerful tool in materials research since the energies of thermal neutrons match well with typical range of structural and dynamical parameters present in liquid and solid materials. Unlike X-rays, neutrons are sensitive to light elements (for example, Hydrogen) and provide ample contrast between neighboring elements (e.g. Iron and Cobalt) in the periodic table. Moreover, neutrons carry a magnetic moment and they can also be used to test the arrangement of magnetic moments in a material. However, neutron scattering is a rather specialized technique and it requires the use of national user facilities, where a large neutron flux is produced either as a fission product in a research reactor or through spallation products at a spallation source. The Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE) at Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) operates one of the two neutron spallation sources in the US, the other being the world’s premier spallation source, the Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL).

The large through-put of neutron-scattering studies and the unique information gained in many research fields led to an increasing demand of trained neutron scatterers, therefore essentially all neutron-scattering user facilities worldwide introduced training programs specific to their facility. The LANSCE School on Neutron Scattering was first introduced in 2004, to date eleven LANSCE Schools have run with the final school in 2015. Unlike other neutron scattering schools in the US, the LANSCE Schools were designed as topical schools that focused on research areas where neutron-scattering can or had made important impacts to the progress in those chosen research fields. The LANSCE Schools offered full support for participation to a limited number of about 30 graduate students, predominantly in the early stages of their research career. Student participants were selected through a competitive selection process, based on qualifications, match of student interest with the research topic of the particular school, and diversity considerations. Each school was run for 9-10 days, and they consisted of presentations by world-known experts in neutron-scattering and the research topic and hands-on experimental studies.

The current NSF grant was used to provide full support for student travel and meals over the duration of the 10th and 11th LANSCE Schools with the topics on Geosciences & Materials in Extreme Environments and Materials at the Mesoscale, respectively. The remaining budget for the two schools was provided by LANL and the Department of Energy, and it was used to cover lodging costs, instructor support and local expenses. Figures 1 and 2 provide photographs of the participants (students, lecturers and organizers) of both schools, and Figures 3 and 4 provide their demographics.

The main goal of the LANSCE Schools was to significantly grow the community of expert neutron scatterers, particularly with females and minorities. The two schools combined were able to accommodate sixty-six student participants, of which one self-identified as Native American, three as Black or African-American, twelve as Hispanic or Latino, twenty as Asian, twenty-three as White Caucasian, seven did not self-identify, and twenty-five of all participants are female.
